Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Intro to multivariate statistics using R.
Multivariate Statistics, computing for statistics.
I learned about data manipulation in multiple dimensions, as well as how to look at datasets and see trends and patterns using R programming.
Multivariate statistical techniques: Principle Components Analysis (PCA), Clustering Analysis, Discriminant Analysis, MANOVA, Ordination, Factor Analysis and Structural Equations Modeling.

I learned that there's a lot more to statistics and data analysis than just the hypothesis-testing covered in lower-level stats classes. I learned more complex techniques for looking at data that I can apply later in my career, even though I'm a psych major, I hope to go into research.
I learned how to apply a wide variety of statistical tools to large data sets. It tied together methods and tools I'd learned throughout my time at Yale in a useful and engaging way.
In-depth knowledge of how to perform (and the logic behind) multivariate statistical tests such as PCA, clustering, discriminant analysis, MANOVA, ordination, factor analysis, etc.
Taking this course I learned a lot about how to analyze statistics on a multivariate level, specifically running multiple tests and overlaying data or charts to see and notice trends.
I don't really think I learned enough. The material wasn't taught very well and I found myself just learning how to do the psets rather than understanding the content.
Multivariate stats, R. basically more useful applications of statistical methods.
I learnt how to work with different statistical methods to process multivariate data.
Learned a lot of statistical analyses that I plan to use in my own research.
Numerous multivariate statistical techniques.
I learned how to use R for the first time.
Advanced level statistics methods to tackle more challenging and diverse data sets.
pca, manova
I think you learn a decent amount about how to run tests on different data types, though perhaps less about drawing actual conclusions from them.
I learned about the theory behind many statistics tests used in social sciences.
Knowledge of multivariate stats.
Learned several different multivariate statistical analysis techniques.
Gain a better understanding of different multivariate statistics technique. Was able to apply them to some data as well with the problem sets and final project.
Nothing. Well, how to do discriminant analysis because that's the only thing I put time into outside of class to actually learn.
A lot of ways to analyze multivariate data sets.

I received a big overview of different kinds of multivariate analysis including PCA, Discriminant Analysis, MANOVA, Ordination, and more, as well as a basic introduction to linear algebra to supplement some of the math required for these analyses.
I learned a variety of multivariate statistical analysis techniques.
We learned PCA, cluster analysis, discriminant analysis, MANOVA, ordination, and factor analysis.

-multivariate stats techniques
-how to think critically about what technique to use
-how to use R, SAS, SPSS, Minitab to do these analyses
We went through a handful of multivariate methods one at a time. JDRS provides great R code, though he doesnt explicitly teach it.
I learned about multivariate statistical methods including PCA, factor analysis, discriminant analysis, cluster analysis, and MANOVA and practiced implementing them on a real dataset in R.

I became much more aware of multivariate analysis methods and how to evaluate datasets using them in R. I wish I gained more exposure to Stata, SPSS, SAS, as well but there was not a lot of support for learning new languages.
Good, basic understanding of multivariate statistical techniques.
Preview into multivariate statistics

Variety of applied Multivariate Statistics methods. A great strength of the course is that you learn when and how to use various techniques; the mathematical background on the 'why' is a bit lacking-- but that is in fact a strength for some students.
Multivariate stats

This course gives a great foundation for understanding the interesting field of multivariate statistics. You are left to your own to learn to code the problem sets, but the professor gives extensive examples. You really learn how to apply and interpret advanced statistical concepts.
Better knowledge of R, SAS, and other programming skills as well as multivariate stats.
PCA, Cluster Analysis, Discriminant Analysis, MANOVA.

I learned various types of multivariate statistical analysis -- when to use each of them and their assumptions, interpretations, and implementation in R. We were able to use and analyze real datasets.
I learned about various methods in multivariate analysis and somewhat the code to implement those methods.

I learned a variety of multivariate statistical techniques including, Principal Components Analysis, Cluster Analysis, Discriminant Analysis, MANOVA, Ordination, and Factor Analysis. Perhaps most importantly, I learned to apply these techniques to *real data* (a dataset that we picked for ourselves) while working with a group, which also strengthened communication skills. Emphasis was placed on a conceptual understanding of topics and interpreting the results, rather than a strictly rigorous and proof-heavy curriculum. Also, everything was done within RStudio and I feel like I greatly improved as a coder while working through this course.
Very well-taught, and overall a great introduction that is not terribly difficult.

This course is great - but to the point at which it might be a little too chill. All lectures are recorded/streamed, so you feel even less of a need to go to class, and often times you just end up never watching the lecture. You get what you put into the course - so if you really want to learn it, you can definitely go to lecture and do the homeworks - otherwise, a lot of times many groups would just read the notes and do the homework the night before. JDRS is a great professor though.

This course is a blessing and a curse; JRS is a FABULOUS lecturer, and he records all the classes and has incredibly comprehensive notes with very straightforward problem sets. Because of this, there isn't a HUGE incentive to go to class, especially if you have a lot of statistics experience. I was able to complete all the problem sets simply looking at the slide deck, which is really convenient, but I would have gotten more out of the class if I actually went (this is totally on me, but it's easy to fall into this mindset).

Strengths: the material in the course is great - a lot of statistical techniques that I have not learned of before and that may actually be useful for the future. Also, JDRS is great and presents the material in a way that is very easy to understand. Not much work at all - just 6 psets and a final project that can all be done in groups.

JDRS is an excellent lecturer and does his absolute best with the material he has, but the lectures can still get very, VERY dry if you don't have any kind of math background. I would suggest focusing less on the nitty gritty math details in lecture (which you overall don't need to know for the problem sets) and doing more actual coding. Toward the end of the semester, I found myself not even watching the lectures and then teaching myself how to do the homeworks with the code Jonathan provided (which was super helpful). There is also a VERY long turnaround to get grades back on homeworks (sometimes a homework would be due before you even got the grade for the one before it).
The course did a great job of not getting bogged down in theory to the point of being incomprehensible. I wouldn't do anything to change this course.
The lectures were clear and all notes were always posted, along with helpful R (or SAS, etc.) files with examples. Excellently design for student learning.
A strength of this course is the ability to use any number of programs to complete the problem sets. It incorporates a greater range of stats knowledge because people can use R, SPSS, Stata, etc.
Very hard to listen to lectures because they're all recorded and there is little motivation to actually go. Very relaxed though and easy fifth class!
The content is very interesting but I think there needs to be a little more explanation of the theory so we students can understand what technique to use when.
Group aspect is good, helps a lot with getting stuff done. I think that switching between a bunch of different programs can be a little annoying sometimes.

A strength of this course is that the instructor was very clear and went through the content of the course in a thorough and clear way that was beneficial to learning. A point of improvement would be to offer more detailed feedback about mistakes that were made in the various homework assignments and how such mistakes can be avoided in the future.

Strengths: very flexible, easy to catch up on content, friendly prof.
Weaknesses: You get what you put into it, and it's easy to fall behind on material.
Check in more on students (more than half of the class never comes to the class).
We can work in groups so I got to meet new people throughout the course.

I felt a lot of the math and "how this works" behind the methods we learned as largely glossed over*. Because of that, psets were largely finding the code chunks we needed from his notes and plugging in our data. For that reason, I don't think I have nearly as strong of a grasp on the details material. Rather, I have more of an overall views and could do it in R if I had to. 

*To be fair a lot of it is fairly advanced math, linear algebra, etc., hopefully I can take a later stats+math courses that go into the background of these methods
nothing really

Strengths: the problem sets give students the opportunity to apply statistical methods to REAL WORLD DATA!

Weakness: There was a big emphasis on SPSS in the class, although most students used R rather than SPSS for their data sets.

Strengths are that it teaches you a variety of data analysis techniques but a weakness is that they are very hard to understand. I don't feel like I completely understand any of the material or how to analyze the results of the data analysis technique, even though I know how to do it in R
Strength was the course's flexibility. Weakness was the group element. It made it hard to be fully accountable for the material.
JDRS is an amazing lecturer!

Engaging lectures. Lecturer was able to explain difficult concepts in a way that was accessible to a broad range of audience. However, the course does not go into much theory and it would have been more beneficial to get more into the theory of the techniques taught in class.

There are so many problems with this course: the format makes it easy to never go to lecture, never watch the (recorded) lecures, and copy from his notes to the homework. The examples are very pertinent to graduate students (many of whom are working on projects that are similar to the ones he discusses), but the material isn't as relevant to undergraduate students who are not actively conducting research. Unfortunately, Yale S&DS has a dearth of other courses at this level (past the beginner level, more applied and not super theoretical courses), so many students don't really have another choice, and the alternatives either aren't running or are just as bad. Seriously, though, I had so many friends taking this course at the same time and none of us learned anything besides how to copy his code to do the psets. That said, he's a good lecture and the lecture slides do make for some good reference material for later on.
It's very structured which is nice.
This class was good. I think that not having exams makes it a lot lower stakes.
This course had interesting homework assignments. I liked that we got to work with our own datasets, which meant that we got to do an actual project based on a real dataset.
Great content, easy to keep up, fun lectures.

It was both a strength and a weakness that this course was so self-directed and customizable. It was very convenient to have video lectures and no exams, but that meant I wasn't very motivated to actually learn the material, so long as I could follow the provided example code to complete the assignments. I also did feel like the class focused on the application of the statistical methods we covered more than the theory, so I feel very reliant on built-in software packages-- I sort of wish we'd had to write our own functions at some point to really learn how all this stuff works. But really, it's mostly my fault for not putting the hours in-- it's just that this course was a lot easier to blow off than my other courses.
The TA office hours could be located closer to central campus. Otherwise, the accessibility of the lectures online was very helpful for my learning.

Strengths: lectures recorded, group psets/projects 

Weakness: group psets - east to rely on group members and not worry so much about learning the material oneself

Strengths: You learn how to really use the skills learnt using real life data
Weaknesses: You can get away without learning much; Google can reveal just as much. The problem set grading is opaque as you can use your own data set.

Strengths: recorded lecture. Never have to go to class. Easy to understand. Easy problem sets. 

Weaknesses: for a lot of the hw you can base it off the example code so at the end its easy to realize you didnt learn as much as you thought.

The material is interesting, but JDRS does a PHENOMENAL job teaching. He is smart, engaging, funny, and knows how to explain topics well. He singlehandedly makes this class great. The problem sets were usually insightful and enjoyable, but occasionally they were not worded well or asked questions that were impossible to do in one of the recommended coding languages.
Strengths were the slides and lectures. Weakness was the assignments - too broad.

This was much more my fault than the class's, but the entire class is recorded and Professor Reuning-Scherer puts no pressure on you to attend class in person, so its very easy to become disengaged with the class. I think it might have been better to encourage students to come to class in-person, and use the videos as a backup.

The course is very accommodating and flexible, with video lectures and biweekly group problem sets. JDRS is also very enthusiastic about the course. The course could be improved by having better organized content and slides -- I oftentimes felt that the course only haphazardly tried to go into the mathematics/mechanics of each form of statistical analysis. I would have much preferred that the course either took the mathematics/mechanics head-on and went into more detail or chose not to explain the mechanics and only give a brief overview, as I felt that I didn't fully understand the math behind the multivariate analysis techniques given the brief amount of time we spent on it. I also wish that we got more detailed feedback on the problem sets (more than just a grade on the rubric) and got it much earlier so that we could incorporate this feedback into the subsequent problem set.

Strengths: good explanations of theory behind methods/approaches, accessible video lecture format 
Weaknesses: the lack of full explanation behind the code (many things the professor just provided source code rather than walking us through how to actually perform that technique), psets that could not be completed in one language (if you are going to say you can use any language to complete the homework, then make sure you provide enough instruction on how to do so or write a pset that you do not need to switch between programs to finish)

*Strengths:* JDRS is an excellent teacher. Hes readily available, friendly, and patient. Hes very knowledgeable and knows how to make difficult, abstract concepts engaging, interesting, and accessible. The class is extremely well structured. Everything was very organized and laid out far in advance which made for relatively low stress. JDRS posts comprehensive PDF coursenotes (with lots of graphics and jokes!) on Canvas which are a great resource for reviewing the class material; there is no textbook for this course, and JDRS coursenotes are a worthy replacement! JDRS also posts sample code for the homework psets to help students who have less experience coding getting started, and I feel like regardless of your coding background, your coding will improve by working through this course. Another great plus is that the psets encourage you to apply the multivariate techniques taught in class to a dataset of your (and your partners -- up to 3 others!) choosing, so the work youre doing feels personally meaningful and interesting. If one weeks technique isnt applicable JDRS also posts loaner datasets. Psets are due every two weeks. Grading is based on your explanation/rationalization of results, and psets often have opportunity for extra credit for completing optional, nonparametric techniques at the end. The final project is pretty much an amalgamation of your previous psets. Classes are livestreamed and archived online, so if you miss a class you can go back and watch it whenever you want from your laptop. TA office hours are also held nearly everyday, and JDRS has office hours twice a week. I thoroughly enjoyed this course.

*Weaknesses:* In some places, the lack of lots of math left a few questions that couldnt really be answered unambiguously, but such is the nature of teaching with an emphasis on conceptual understanding, which overall I believe was very effective. The course notes had a few equations that made conceptual sense, but they seemed to be obscure enough that I couldnt corroborate them anywhere online, and wiki gave different math definitions for the same operations. Also grading conceptually on analysis meant that sometimes it could be unclear what constituted a complete, full-credit answer (answers were always to be written in plain English). Before turning in your pset, it really is necessary to check in with a TA to have them skim your work and get their opinion on whether or not theyre looking for a line or two that you omitted. I feel like in general though, weaknesses here are pretty minor and this is clearly a course JDRS has spent a lot of time over the years refining to where it is today.
Yes! If you're looking for a 300-level course that is not too difficult this is the one.

This is an awesome class to learn a bunch of complicated statistical techniques in a pretty low stress environment. The lectures are good at keeping the material interesting and the problem sets cover what we did in class pretty exactly.
Take it if you really want to learn it - otherwise it's kinda considered a stat gut.
I would recommend this as a fifth class for S&DS majors  the workload is very low but you still learn a lot.

I would recommend this course to anyone that is willing to make an effort in this class. The material in this class is great - a lot of statistical techniques that I have not learned of before and that may actually be useful for the future. However, there is not much work in this class, just 6 psets and a final project that can all be done in groups, so make sure you keep up with the lectures and actually do all the work. If done right, this class is fantastic.

Take it if you want to have a broader knowledge of statistical analysis techniques. If you have a math background, the lectures might be interesting, but if you don't, you'll have no idea what is going on, and you can skip them as long as you follow Jonathan's guides for how to do the homeworks.

This course is a great way to learn how to apply many of the things learned but not attempted in other courses. There's a sense of accomplishment from actually using what we learned in class in a practical manner.
Yes - if you want to learn multivariate stats in a relatively painless (and honestly, pretty fun) way, take this class!
I would definitely recommend this as a fun stats course for anyone looking to get past intro stats.
If you need an easy stats course that allows you to explore something you're interested in, then yes!
Yeah, if you have taken/are taking 230 you will be fine. Just have a group of friends you can do stuff with.
Yes, it is a great course to pick up multivariate statistics, especially for social science majors.
Yes, you learn a lot of useful multivariate techniques.

There is a lot of overlap between this class and S&DS 365. All of the lectures are recorded which is nice. There are no exams, only homework and a final paper that is essentially a compilation of the homework. You can work in a group. I ended up choosing not to since I didn't know anyone in the class but still found the work very doable (especially since he provides so much code that only requires minimal modification).
If you want simple exposure to multivariate statistics with only a few straightforward projects to work on (in groups or alone) the whole semester (read: a gut), then sure.
Yes because you get to practice multivariate data analysis for data that you are interested in.

Yes. Very cool to learn an array of statistical methods that are definitely applicable and allow to actually begin to tackle data in a meaningful way. WHile I feel the course could've been better on the foundations of each method, I do now have a much, much wider and varied spread of tools in my stats toolkit because of this course. The data we looked at and seeing how these new methods work is really cool.

I think it's a pretty low-key 5th credit class. You have 6 homeworks and one final project, and you work as a group so it is pretty chill. It's also nice being able to watch lecture whenever you want, though I must say it is occasionally hard to pay attention to the video, particularly when he uses examples in a program you don't use. Besides that, I think it's a good class.
Yes, I think it was a good application of statistical concepts to real-life problems. It also is a very manageable workload.
Yes, for a more chill S&DS elective (however, the material is still pretty hard to understand)
Yes if you want to take it seriously.
Yes
In general, no. But Yale doesn't really have other Stats courses as options, especially in the Spring, so I guess take it if you need to?
yes, it's a great course for S&DS majors

This was a great course. I learned a lot of theory through the lectures and really got a lot out of it. The psets were very straightforward and not too difficult. The rubric seemed very vague as if to try and help students out. Also, the group psets were very nice. I did little work on my own, and thus may have suffered in learning to apply the theories I'd learned.

I would recommend this gem for any S&DS majors. If you're taking this during your senior year (i.e. after taking several semesters in R) then it's going to be a slam dunk. The professor provides tons of code examples, so an experienced coder will find that the setting up the analysis takes very little time compared to many classes (where much of the time is spent learning the packages, troubleshooting, etc). Highly recommend.
Yeah, this course is great.
Yes, this is an excellent course. Professor Reuning-Scherer is an amazing instructor and made the materials very digestible.
I absolutely recommend.

Your experience of this course is highly dependent on how much work you put into it. Since it's a semester-long group project, it is entirely possible to not go to lecture, not watch the video lectures, and still do well just by looking at the example code for the problem sets and applying it to your own dataset. That doesn't feel very fulfilling, though, so I can't say I'd actually recommend doing that, even though it does help out if you're taking a lot of heavy-workload classes at the same time. I wish that I'd gone to more lectures so that I could have had a better understanding of the statistical methods-- though the class was more application-focused than theory-focused to begin with.
Yes, this course is very interesting for any student in the social sciences who wishes to gain a deeper understanding of more sophisticated analytical techniques.
I definitely would suggest. The professor is very accessible and he makes sure that the topics are easy to understand.

If your interested in an intro to multiple different multivariate statistical methods of analysis than yes. JDRS is a good professor, he records the lectures so you dont have to go to class, and you can work in a group on all psets and projects.
Yes! Easy but you learn a decent amount.
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. You learn a lot, and JDRS is great!
Yes.
If you want to learn about a wider variety of statistical techniques than you get in 230 or 238 this is a good course to gain some understanding of how and when to use multivariate techniques.
Yes! You learn so much in this class and have the opportunity to apply it to a subject area you like. Its a must take!

I would only recommend this course to another student if they are willing to go to the actual lecture and not just watch the video lectures -- Given the infrequent nature of problem sets, it's really difficult to learn from just the problem sets and reading the slides, and students won't get much from the course if they don't actively try to go to lecture.
Yes, despite the occasional lack of explanation and generally low buy in into the class, the material is still interesting enough to warrant taking it.

I would highly recommend this course to other students. I learned so much about multivariate statistical techniques (emphasis in 363 is on learning techniques to apply to data, vs. 361 where emphasis is on analyzing data and choosing techniques) with both a moderately in-depth mathematical understanding as well as a very strong visual/conceptual understanding. It really changes how you think about statistics in general. JDRS is great, the course structure is great, the online component is great, choosing your own data and your own group is great, and working extensively with R is great. Grading was fair and there were no surprises in this course -- everything was laid out far in advance which made for relatively low stress. JDRS even extended certain pset deadlines when he saw people were in crunch-mode around midterms. He really cares about all his students and wants to make sure everyone understands. This was easily one of the best classes Ive taken all year.
